text: a flash of infrared light is all it
takes to activate this piece of striped
plastic it bends that it's black and
hinges because of tiny infrared
sensitive carbon tubes contained within
at first glance this flexible doohickey
might not seem like it has anything to
do with robots after all robots we see
on TV and in movies typically have hard
frames and metal parts but scientists
these days want to make robots out of
softer materials ones that are more
flexible and can carry fragile objects
without breaking them so researchers at
the University of wisconsin-milwaukee
have designed this striped piece of
plastic to make that vision a reality
they mix some liquid crystal polymers
and carbon nanotubes together and
stretch them during fabrication to make
a reactive plastic sheet then they stuck
the sheet on top of one made out of
silicon by itself this by layer of
plastic remains motionless but when hit
with a flash of infrared light it jolts
into action the nano tubes inside heat
up significantly and they trigger the
liquid crystal polymers nearby to become
disordered that phase transition as it's
called put strain on the lower silicon
layer causing the whole assembly to curl
up but what good are curling bending
sheets of hinged plastic well the
Milwaukee scientists demonstrated that
the material could be used like a Venus
flytrap to capture and delicately lift
very foreign objects into the air and
they demonstrated that they could make a
strip of the stuff walk slowly up a
textured incline by alternately shining
infrared light on its front and middle
sections although it might not be
collecting rocks on Mars or saving the
planet from destruction anytime soon
this new nanotubes liquid crystal
composite could inch toward becoming the
commonly used robotics material in a
future age this is Lauren wolf reporting
for chemical and engineering news
